  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours

    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
If there isn’t significant improvement
  on the ground in Iraq,
  the president won’t be able to hold onto some of his key Republican
  support in Congress. That’s the message moderate Republicans had for
  President Bush after they pulled him into a private meeting for what has been
  called a “very frank” discussion earlier this week. Our chief
  White House correspondent, Jim Axelrod, will have details about that meeting.
  Sharyl Attkisson will report from Capitol Hill on how Congress and President
  Bush may now be working toward a compromise on the crucial issue of setting
  benchmarks for progress in Iraq.
  
 
The maker of OxyContin and three of its
  current and former executives pleaded guilty today to misleading the public
  about how addictive the powerful drug can be. A U.S. Attorney said the
  company unleashed an easily abused drug on an “unsuspecting and
  unknowing public.” The company has agreed to pay hundreds of millions
  of dollars. Correspondent Bob Orr will have the story.
 
Two forces of nature are clashing in the
  Southeast as massive wildfires continue to torch the Florida-Georgia border.
  Not far away, the first named storm of the year has brought a sprinkling of
  rain to help firefighters there, but tinderbox conditions elsewhere in the country
  are contributing to new fires. Kelly Cobiella will report.
 
It might be heating up all along the
  East Coast – for good – if a new NASA report is right. Randall
  Pinkston will share the disturbing report about just how hot our planet could
  get before the turn of the century.
 
Elizabeth Palmer will report from London on the news today that one of America’s best friends,
  British Prime Minister Tony Blair, is stepping down.  We’ll look back
  at his decade in office.
 
To cap our broadcast, Kelly Wallace will
  have an Eye on the American Family report. She’ll take a look at the
  phenomenon called “opting out.” It’s the idea that some high-powered
  career moms over the past decade have been deciding to stay at home with
  their kids rather than work full-time. Now some experts say when mothers stop
  working, it may not be voluntary. 
 
I hope you’ll join us,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
